Title: Drawing of Jacob Dodson, a 19th century African American explorer, by Sam Patrick, circa 1969
AltTitle.other: Explorers of African descent
Description.note: Print of a drawing by Sam Patrick representing Jacob Dodson, of the John C. Fremont expeditions to California. In this drawing, Dodson wears a fringed suede or leather shirt with a neckerchief and a cowboy hat.   |~|Jacob Dodson accompanied John C. Fremont on three expeditions to explore the Western frontier. Dodson was a free born African American whose family worked in the service of Fremont’s father-in-law, Missouri Senator Thomas Hart Benton.|~|Samuel James Patrick began his art studies in Philadelphia. By 1925 he had moved to Los Angeles and enrolled at the Otis Art Institute. He was then a staff artist at the Los Angeles Times for over 40 years. He published an article "Jacob Dodson Helped Open the West,"  4 Jan. 1969 in the Washington Evening Star. He provided the illustrations for the book "They Had a Dream" (1970) by George Reasons.
Description.caption: Photo label: Jacob Dodson, a negro from Washington, D. C., was a valuable member of all the John C. Fremont expeditions to California which helped pave the way for the conquest of this state by Americans. Dodson is credited with the discovery of Fremont Pass near Los Angeles and accompanied Fremont on his famous ride from Los Angeles to Monterey and back, the most remarkable on record for speed and distance on horseback. This drawing of Dodson is the work of artist Sam Patrick for the Times Mirror Press.
Name.subject: Dodson, Jacob, b. 1825
Source?: Explorers of African descent

Title: Drawing of York, a late 18th-early 19th century African American explorer, by Sam Patrick, circa 1969
AltTitle.other: Explorers of African descent
Description.note: Print of a drawing by Sam Patrick representing the explorer known as York. York is shown wearing a neckerchief and a fur cap with an attached feather.  |~|York is best known for his participation with the Lewis and Clark Expedition.|~|Samuel James Patrick began his art studies in Philadelphia. By 1925 he had moved to Los Angeles and enrolled at the Otis Art Institute. He was then a staff artist at the Los Angeles Times for over 40 years. He provided the illustrations for the book "They Had a Dream" (1970) by George Reasons.
Description.caption: Photo label: York, a negro, with the Lewis and Clark expedition / Drawn by Sam Patrick from "They Had a Dream" by Geo. Reasons, Volume I.
Name.subject: York, b. 1770
Source?: Explorers of African descent

Title: Drawing of Estevanico, a 16th century African explorer, by Sam Patrick, circa 1969
AltTitle.other: Explorers of African descent
Description.note: Print of a drawing by Sam Patrick representing Estevanico (Estevan) (circa 1500-1539) one of the first native Africans to reach the continental United States. |~|Estevanico is known by several names, including Esteban de Dorantes, Estebanico, and Esteban the Moor, or Mustafa Zemmouri. Enslaved as a youth by the Portuguese, he was sold to a Spanish nobleman and taken in 1527 on the Spanish Narváez expedition to establish a colony in Florida. For eight years, he traveled with Álvar Núñez Cabeza de Vaca, Andrés Dorantes de Carranza, and Alonso del Castillo Maldonado across northern New Spain (present-day U.S. Southwest and northern Mexico). They finally reached Spanish forces in Mexico City in 1536. Later Estevanico served as the main guide for a return expedition to the Southwest. Spaniards believe that he was killed in the Zuni city of Hawikuh in 1539. (Wikipedia). |~|Samuel James Patrick began his art studies in Philadelphia. By 1925 he had moved to Los Angeles and enrolled at the Otis Art Institute. He was then a staff artist at the Los Angeles Times for over 40 years. He provided the illustrations for the book "They Had a Dream" (1970) by George Reasons.
Description.caption: Photo label: Estevanico
Name.subject: Estevan, -1539
Source?: Explorers of African descent

Title: Drawing of Manuel Camero, one of the founders of Los Angeles in 1781, by Sam Patrick, circa 1969
AltTitle.other: Manuel Camero, founder of Los Angeles, of African descent, and one of first city councilmen.
Description.note: Print of a drawing by Sam Patrick representing Manuel Camero. He is shown wearing a shirt and a headband. |~|Manuel Camero was from el Real del Rosario, Sinaloa. He enlisted as a soldier at the age of 30 in 1780 and served as Los Angeles Regidor (city councilman) after arriving in 1781, he died in 1819.|~|Samuel James Patrick began his art studies in Philadelphia. By 1925 he had moved to Los Angeles and enrolled at the Otis Art Institute. He was then a staff artist at the Los Angeles Times for over 40 years. He provided the illustrations for the book "They Had a Dream" (1970) by George Reasons.
Description.caption: Photo label: Manuel Camero a mulatto, one of the founders of Los Angeles and one of its first City Councilmen / Drawing by Samuel Patrick, former L.A. Times staff artist.
Name.subject: Camero, Manuel, circa 1740-1819
Source?: Manuel Camero, founder of Los Angeles, of African descent, and one of first city councilmen.

Title: Painting of Jose Cesario Moreno and his wife Maria Guadalupe Gertrudis Perez, 1781 founders of Los Angeles
AltTitle.other: Jose and Maria Guadalupe Moreno, founders of Los Angeles of African descent, and their descendants.
Description.note: Painting of Jose and Maria Guadalupe Moreno on horseback at the LA County Museum of Natural History.|~|Jose Cesario Moreno and his wife Maria Guadalupe Gertrudis Perez were from Real del Rosario, Sinaloa. They were among 12 families from Rosario recruited in 1781 to settle in Los Angeles. Moreno served as a Los Angeles Regidor; he is buried at Mission San Gabriel.
Description.caption: Photo label: Jose Moreno, mulatto, and his wife Maria Guadalupe, Milata, founders of Los Angeles / From a painting by an artist at the L.A. County Museum of Natural History.
Name.subject: Moreno, Jose Cesario, 1757-1806|~|Perez, Maria Guadalupe Gertrudis, 1762-1860
Source?: Jose and Maria Guadalupe Moreno, founders of Los Angeles of African descent, and their descendants.

Name.subject: Moreno, Manuel, b. circa 1825
Source?: Jose and Maria Guadalupe Moreno, founders of Los Angeles of African descent, and their descendants.

Title: Painting of Luis and Maria Petra Quintero, 1781 founders of Los Angeles, of African descent
AltTitle.other: Luis and Maria Petra Quintero, founders of Los Angeles, of African descent.
Description.note: Painting representing Luis and Maria Petra Quintero, founders of Los Angeles, standing beside two horses, by a staff artist of the Los Angeles County Museum of Natural History.|~|Luis Manuel Quintero was a New Spain-Colonial tailor from Guadalajara, Jalisco, who later became one of the 44 original settlers of the Pueblo de Los Angeles (present-day Los Angeles, California) on September 4, 1781. Quintero's wife María Petra Rubio was born near 1741 and came from Álamos, Sonora. She was described as a mulatta, or a person of mixed Spanish and African descent. (Wikipedia)
Description.caption: Photo label: Luis Quinteros and his wife Maria Petra Quintero, L.A. founders of African descent. Painting by staff artist of the L.A. County Museum of Natural History.
Name.subject: Quinteros, Luis, b. circa 1725 - 1810|~|Quinteros, María Petra Rubio, b. circa 1741
Source?: Luis and Maria Petra Quintero, founders of Los Angeles, of African descent.

Title: Ysidro Reyes, half-owner of Rancho Boca de Santa Monica and descendant of Juan Francisco Reyes, circa 1853-1861
AltTitle.other: Family and descendants of Juan Francisco Reyes, alcalde, 1793-1795.
Description.note: Ysidro Reyes, son of Juan Francisco Reyes, acquired half of the Mexican Land Grant called the Rancho Boca de Santa Monica (present day Santa Monica Canyon, the Pacific Palisades, and parts of Topanga Canyon). |~|Juan Francisco Reyes, was a mulatto settler from Mexico who arrived shortly after the original settlers of 1781. In 1784, he received the Spanish Crown’s land-grant for Rancho Los Encinos. After selling it back, he received the land grant for Lompoc. He became the first alcalde (mayor) of the Los Angeles pueblo in 1790.
Description.caption: Photo label: Ysidro Reyes. "Lived at Santa Monica Canyon and his father worked a large tract of land extending to what is now Hollywood. He was sent by his father to the Brea Tar Pits to sell tar to the Los Angeles people who used it for their roofs. Photo is from: Chas. Prudhomme [Charles J. Prudhomme (1854-1934) collection of historic Los Angeles photographs, California Historical Society, Huntington Library]
Name.subject: Reyes, Ysidro, 1813-1861
Source?: Family and descendants of Juan Francisco Reyes, alcalde, 1793-1795.

Title: Refugio Reyes de Roberts, great-granddaughter of Juan Francisco Reyes, circa 1870s
AltTitle.other: Family and descendants of Juan Francisco Reyes, alcalde, 1793-1795.
Description.note: Juan Francisco Reyes, was a mulatto settler from Mexico who arrived shortly after the original settlers of 1781. In 1784, he received the Spanish Crown’s land-grant for Rancho Los Encinos. After selling it back, he received the land grant for Lompoc. He became the first alcalde (mayor) of the Los Angeles pueblo in 1790.
Description.caption: Photo label: Refugio Reyes de Roberts, great granddaughter of Juan Francisco Reyes, Alcalde [mayor, of Los Angeles] 1793-1795. Original portrait from Rancho Cuyama, Ventura County. The C. C. Pierce Collection, Historical Photographs, 1572 W. Pico Blvd., L.A.
Name.subject: Reyes de Roberts, Refugio
Source?: Family and descendants of Juan Francisco Reyes, alcalde, 1793-1795.

In 1784, he received the Spanish Crown’s land-grant for Rancho Los Encinos. After selling it back, he received the land grant for Lompoc. He became the first alcalde (mayor) of the Los Angeles pueblo in 1790.

AltTitle.other: Family and descendants of Juan Francisco Reyes, alcalde, 1793-1795.
Description.note: Juan Chevez, great-great-grandson of Juan Francisco Reyes, outside the old adobe hacienda once owned by his ancestor in 1920.|~|Juan Francisco Reyes, was a mulatto settler from Mexico who arrived shortly after the original settlers of 1781. In 1784, he received the Spanish Crown’s land-grant for Rancho Los Encinos. After selling it back, he received the land grant for Lompoc. He became the first alcalde (mayor) of the Los Angeles pueblo in 1790.
Description.caption: Photo label: Juan Chevez. This is [the] great great grandson of Los Angeles' first Black Mayor, Don Juan Francisco Reyes, 1793-1795. [He] is shown in front of an old adobe hacienda once owned by his ancestor. Photo was taken in 1920. Courtesy of Los Angeles Public Library.

Title: Stagecoach driven by Gus Thompson, circa 1870-1890
AltTitle.other: Stagecoach Drivers and Pony Express Riders
Description.note: Coach with the first pair of horses visible, driven by Gus Thompson, riding over railroad tracks in a town with two buildings and a cart visible in the background. Thompson has his hand raised to his hat.
Description.caption: Photo label: Gus Thompson's carriage
Name.subject: Thompson, Gus
Source?: Stagecoach Drivers and Pony Express Riders

Title: Nathaniel Smith, pioneer and stagecoach driver in Mendocino County, circa 1880-1900
AltTitle.other: Stagecoach Drivers and Pony Express Riders
Description.note: Studio portrait of Nathaniel Smith, a Mendocino County pioneer who drove a stagecoach. He is seated on a wooden stool in front of a landscape backdrop.|~|Nathaniel Smith was a free black man from Maryland who purchased (together with his partner Francisco Faria) a tract of a Mexican land grant which extended from the north bank of the Garcia River to the south bank of the Rio Grande (Big River) in Mendocino County.
Description.caption: Photo label: Smith, Nathaniel (Mendocino Co. pioneer). Staging in the Mendocino Redwoods (see Overland Monthly Sept. 1891, p. 270, v. 20 #117). Credit Calif. Historical Society, S. F. Secured from James Abajian.
Name.subject: Smith, Nathaniel, d. 1906
Source?: Stagecoach Drivers and Pony Express Riders

Title: George Monroe, stagecoach driver, 1886
AltTitle.other: Stagecoach Drivers and Pony Express Riders
Description.note: Portrait of George Monroe, stagecoach driver, in a dress shirt, matching pinstripe vest and trousers, watch chain and hat, standing outside. |~|George Monroe rode a stagecoach between Merced and Mariposa and became a renowned stage driver. He drove three United States presidents into Yosemite, Ulysses S. Grant, James A. Garfield and Rutherford B. Hayes, as well as Gen. William T. Sherman. Monroe Meadows in Yosemite is named after him.
Description.caption: Photo label: George Monroe, stagecoach driver, 1886. Drove Pres. Ulysses Grant in Yosemite Valley 1879. Credit Calif. Hist. Soc., S. F. neg. #13559.
Name.subject: Monroe, George, b. 1846 or 47-1886
Source?: Stagecoach Drivers and Pony Express Riders

He drove three United States presidents into Yosemite, Ulysses S. Grant, James A. Garfield and Rutherford B. Hayes, as well as Gen. William T. Sherman. Monroe Meadows in Yosemite is named after him.
Name.subject: Monroe, George, b. 1846 or 47-1886

Title: William Robinson, who carried mail in the Stockton area, circa 1860-1880
AltTitle.other: Stagecoach Drivers and Pony Express Riders
Description.note: Studio portrait of William Robinson, mail rider, in a 3-piece suit.|~|Robinson was hired as a Pony Express rider by Bolivar Roberts to ride the 140-mile route between Merced and Mariposa.
Description.caption: Photo label: William Robinson, Pony Express Rider between the city of Stockton and the gold mining communities. Copied from Goode -- "California's Black Pioneers." Photo courtesy of Pioneer Museum & Haggin Collection.
Name.subject: Robinson, William
Source?: Stagecoach Drivers and Pony Express Riders

Title: Pony Express riders in a painting dating circa 1860 (copy photo 1930-1989)
AltTitle.other: Stagecoach Drivers and Pony Express Riders
Description.note: Print reproduction of a painting of a Pony Express rider bounding down a hill, with American Indians on horseback visible in the distance. This painting is attributed to Frederic Remington below the print, but it has also been attributed to Henry H. Cross (http://www.wyomingtalesandtrails.com/oregontrail4.html).
Description.caption: Photo label: Pony Express Rider from a painting by Frederic Remington published in "Pictorial History of California" U. of Calif. Extension Division, Dept. of Visual Instruction.
Source?: Stagecoach Drivers and Pony Express Riders

Title: James P. Beckwourth, mountain man, explorer, fur trader, circa 1856
AltTitle.other: James P. Beckwourth, mountain man, explorer, fur trader
Description.note: Studio portrait of James P. Beckwourth, wearing a 3-piece suit with a striped vest. |~|James Beckwourth, of mixed-race, and was born into slavery in Virginia. His father was the plantation master, and his mother was an enslaved African American. Beckwourth became  a trapper and explorer in California, where he lived with the Crow Nation for several years and married Crow women. He guided migrants to California and discovered the “Beckwourth Pass” through the mountains between Reno, Nevada and Portola, California.
Description.caption: Photo label: James P. Beckwourth
Name.subject: Beckwourth, James Pierson, 1798-1866
Source?: James P. Beckwourth, mountain man, explorer, fur trader

The illustration appeared in the book buy T. D. Bonner, "The Life and Adventures of James P. Beckwourth: Mountaineer, Scout and Pioneer, and Chief of the Crow Nation of Indians" (1856).|~|James Beckwourth, of mixed-race, and was born into slavery in Virginia. His father was the plantation master, and his mother was an enslaved African American. Beckwourth became  a trapper and explorer in California, where he lived with the Crow Nation for several years and married Crow women. He guided migrants to California and discovered the “Beckwourth Pass” through the mountains between Reno, Nevada and Portola, California.

Source?: James P. Beckwourth, mountain man, explorer, fur trader

His father was the plantation master, and his mother was an enslaved African American. Beckwourth became  a trapper and explorer in California, where he lived with the Crow Nation for several years and married Crow women. He guided migrants to California and discovered the “Beckwourth Pass” through the mountains between Reno, Nevada and Portola, California.

AltTitle.other: Prints and negatives of Beckwourth trading post, Beckwourth Pass monument, and map.
Description.note: Photomechanical print of Beckwourth Trail, with Beckwourth Pass. |~|Beckwourth Trail, that goes through Beckwourth Pass, was used from 1850 to 1855 by immigrants and during the Gold Rush. His father was the plantation master, and his mother was an enslaved African American. Beckwourth became  a trapper and explorer in California, where he lived with the Crow Nation for several years and married Crow women. He guided migrants to California and discovered the “Beckwourth Pass” through the mountains between Reno, Nevada and Portola, California.

Title: African American miner during the California gold rush at Auburn Ravine, Auburn, 1852
AltTitle.other: Gold Rush
Description.note: An African American Miner holding a shovel above a sluice box at Auburn Ravine
Description.caption: Photo label: Negro miner in Auburn Ravine in 1852 during Calif. gold rush. From California State Library.
Source?: Gold Rush

Title: African American and white gold miners at "Spanish Flat," Placerville (vicinity), 1852
AltTitle.other: Gold Rush
Description.note: An African American miner and a white miner use a "long Tom" to sluice gravels at Spanish Flat, a mining camp in El Dorado County just a few miles north of Placerville. An African American and a white miner are on the road behind them with a horse and cart.
Source?: Gold Rush

Title: "Negro Bar" gold mining spot on the American River, Folsom (vicinity), circa 1849
AltTitle.other: Gold Rush
Description.note: Negro Bar, was a large gravel bar on the south side the American River named for the African-American gold miners who discovered gold there during the 1849 California Gold Rush. For a few years, it rewarded the prospectors with a steady yield of coarse gold dust. Now part of Negro Bar State Recreation Area.
Description.caption: Photo label: Courtesy Calif. State Library
Source?: Gold Rush

Title: Timbuctoo mining town site marker, Yuba County (California), 1930-1989
AltTitle.other: Gold Rush
Description.note: Text: Trails of '49 / Site of Timbuctoo / former mining town. This / building was erected in 1855.
Description.caption: Photo back: If this material is under copyright status, it has been reproduced for the purpose of private study only, and must not be further reproduced of distributed without permission of the copyright owner. California State Library. Source: California Section. Picture collection. Neg. #2437.
Source?: Gold Rush

Title: Diorama depicting the 1781 founding of Los Angeles, by artist Joseph Leland Roop in 1931, at the Natural History Museum, Los Angeles
AltTitle.other: Photographs of diorama displays in Natural History Museum
Description.note: Diorama, created in 1931, showing the founding of Los Angeles, with a native Indian man beginning the construction of the first Los Angeles pueblo home, built of sticks, with 22 adults and 22 children arriving at the desert site, with the Los Angeles River and hills in the distance.
Description.caption: Photo label: The founding of Los Angeles, September 4, 1781. This diorama from the Los Angeles County Museum of Natural History shows the founders of Los Angeles, 22 adults and 22 children, arriving at the site for the pueblo. It rightly shows the original pobladores to be of African, Indian and European ancestry.
Sub-series: Monuments, Murals, Exhibitions, and Anniversaries of Early Los Angeles, 1949-1981
Source?: Photographs of diorama displays in Natural History Museum

Title: Diorama depicting the 1846 Battle of San Pasqual, by artist Joseph Leland Roop in 1931, at the Natural History Museum, Los Angeles
AltTitle.other: Photographs of diorama displays in Natural History Museum
Description.note: Diorama, created in 1931, showing the Battle of San Pasqual, which took place in 1846 in San Pasqual Valley in what is not San Diego, California. This battle was a military encounter during the Mexican-American War.
Description.caption: Photo label: The Battle of San Pascual, Diorama on LA County Museum of Natural Hist.
Sub-series: Monuments, Murals, Exhibitions, and Anniversaries of Early Los Angeles, 1949-1981
Source?: Photographs of diorama displays in Natural History Museum

Title: Diorama depicting the 1781 founding of Los Angeles, by artist Joseph Leland Roop in 1931, at the Natural History Museum, Los Angeles
AltTitle.other: Photographs of diorama displays in Natural History Museum
Description.note: Diorama, created in 1931, showing the founding of Los Angeles, detail view of Africans among the 22 adults and 22 children arriving at the desert site, with the Los Angeles River and hills in the distance.
Sub-series: Monuments, Murals, Exhibitions, and Anniversaries of Early Los Angeles, 1949-1981
Source?: Photographs of diorama displays in Natural History Museum

Title: Painting titled "The Capitulation of the Mexican Army at Cahuenga" by artist Carl Oscar Borg, circa 1931
AltTitle.other: Prints of drawings of De Anza Expedition
Description.note: Painting showing the signing of the 1847 Treaty of Cahuenga, which took place at Campo de Cahuenga which is now Universal City, California. Three men in military dress are seated at a table beneath the overhang of a veranda. A man in a poncho and sombrero is barely visible on the right. Men on horseback can be seen in the middle ground, with hills beyond.
Description.caption: Photo label: The Capitulation of the Mexican army at Cahuenga by Carl Oscar Borg; reprinted from West Ways Magazine, Nov. 1931.
Sub-series: Monuments, Murals, Exhibitions, and Anniversaries of Early Los Angeles, 1949-1981
Source?: Prints of drawings of De Anza Expedition

Title: Drawing titled March of Portola to Monterey, by artist Walter W. Francis, published in 1909
AltTitle.other: Prints of drawings of De Anza Expedition
Description.note: Drawing depicting the expedition of Gaspar de Portola to Alta California in 1769. A column of men on horseback on hilly, grassy terrain, with the Pacific Ocean barely visible in the background on the right. |~|The drawing was reproduced in “The March of Portolá and the Discovery of the Bay of San Francisco” by Zoeth S. Eldredge, published by the California Promotion Committee, San Francisco, 1909.
Description.caption: Photomechanical print of drawing. On the print: W. Francis / 09; Print caption: Drawing by Walter Francis, From Original in Bancroft Library.
Sub-series: Monuments, Murals, Exhibitions, and Anniversaries of Early Los Angeles, 1949-1981
Name.subject: Anza, Juan Bautista de, 1693-1740
Source?: Prints of drawings of De Anza Expedition

Title: Award presented to Thelma M. Johnson, a direct descendant of Jose Lara, who was a poblador who participated in the 1781 founding of the pueblo of Los Angeles, 1981
AltTitle.other: Founders Monument, El Pueblo de Los Ángeles
Description.note: Award presented to Thelma M. Johnson, signed by Los Angeles Mayor Tom Bradley and others.
Description.caption: Text of the award: La Ciudad de Los Ángeles / y / La Sociedad histórica de Los Angeles / otorga / Certificado de Distinción a /  Thelma M. Johnson / Descendiente Directo de / José Lara / Poblador que participó en la fundación de / El Pueblo de Nuestra Señora / La Reina de Los Angeles de Porciuncula / El 2 de Septiembre de 1781 / Con motivo del Bicentenario de La Ciudad de Los Ángeles / Junio 5 de 1981
Sub-series: Monuments, Murals, Exhibitions, and Anniversaries of Early Los Angeles, 1949-1981
Name.subject: Johnson, Thelma M.
Source?: Founders Monument, El Pueblo de Los Ángeles

Title: New plaque marking the SE corner of El Pueblo Nuestra Señora La Reina De Los Angeles, Boyle Heights (Los Angeles), 1980
AltTitle.other: Founders Monument, El Pueblo de Los Ángeles
Description.note: People gathered around a plaque commemorating the bicentennial of the founding of El Pueblo de Los Ángeles. The plaque marks the southeast boundary, at 3821 E. Olympic Blvd., in Boyle Heights.
Description.caption: Text of the plaque: This plaque marks the location of the original southeast corner of El Pueblo Nuestra Señora La Reina De Los Angeles De Porciuncula as established in 1781. The greater Boyle Heights Bicentennial Committee, The Los Angeles Historical Society, June 28, 1980. Tom Bradley -- Mayor, Arthur K. Snyder -- Councilman 14th District.
Sub-series: Monuments, Murals, Exhibitions, and Anniversaries of Early Los Angeles, 1949-1981
Source?: Founders Monument, El Pueblo de Los Ángeles

Title: Plaque commemorating "Los Pobladores," who founded Los Angeles at El Pueblo de Los Angeles State Historic Park, Los Angeles, 1980
AltTitle.other: Founders Monument, El Pueblo de Los Ángeles
Description.note: Plaque commemorating "Los Pobladores," the 44 families of Indian, African, and European descent who founded Los Angeles, in its current location at El Pueblo de Los Angeles State Historic Park in Downtown Los Angeles. The plaque provides historical information, the names of the families, the names if individual family members and their racial background.
Description.caption: Text of the plaque: Los Pobladores. The founders of the City of Los Angeles. El Pueblo De La Reina De Los Ángeles [...]
Sub-series: Monuments, Murals, Exhibitions, and Anniversaries of Early Los Angeles, 1949-1981
Source?: Founders Monument, El Pueblo de Los Ángeles

Title: People attending the installation of the plaque marking the location SE corner of El Pueblo Nuestra Señora La Reina De Los Angeles, Boyle Heights (Los Angeles), 1980
AltTitle.other: Founders Monument, El Pueblo de Los Ángeles
Description.note: Site of the plaque commemorating the bicentennial of the founding of El Pueblo de Los Angeles, seen from beneath a banner reading "Greater Boyle Heights Historical-Bicentennial Committee of Los Angeles, California." The plaque marks the southeast boundary, at 3821 E. Olympic Blvd., in Boyle Heights. Six people can be seen standing in front of the plaque.
Sub-series: Monuments, Murals, Exhibitions, and Anniversaries of Early Los Angeles, 1949-1981
Source?: Founders Monument, El Pueblo de Los Ángeles

Title: Artists Hale Woodruff and Charles Alston at Beckwourth Pass during the Golden State Mutual mural research tour, Chilcoot (California), 1948
AltTitle.other: G.S.M. mural research tour with Charles Alston and Hale Woodruff
Description.note: Artists Hale Woodruff (L) and Charles Alston (R) at the landmark at Beckwourth Pass, the lowest mountain pass in the Sierra Nevada mountain range, with notebooks or sketchbooks. They were researching the mural for the new building of the Golden State Mutual Life Insurance Company. |~|Beckwourth Pass was discovered by James P. Beckwourth in 1850. Beckwourth developed Beckwourth Trail, traversing the pass, that was used by immigrants during the Gold Rush from 1851 to 1855. After that, the railroad came into use.
Sub-series: Monuments, Murals, Exhibitions, and Anniversaries of Early Los Angeles, 1949-1981
Name.subject: Woodruff, Hale, 1900-1980|~|Alston, Charles, 1907-1977|~|Golden State Mutual Life Insurance Co.|~|Beckwourth, James Pierson, 1798-1866

Source?: G.S.M. mural research tour with Charles Alston and Hale Woodruff ; Prints and negatives of Beckwourth trading post, Beckwourth Pass monument, and map.

AltTitle.other: G.S.M. Murals Conference and Dedication of artwork
Description.note: Board Chairman George A. Beavers, Jr.; President Norman O. Houston; Controller Helen E. Batiste and architect Paul R. Williams view "The Negro in California History - Exploration and Colonization" mural, by Charles Alston, on the floor at the new Golden State Mutual Life Insurance Co. home office building, just after the panel was unpacked. Williams was the architect of the new Golden State Mutual Life Insurance Co. building completed in 1949.

Title: Group attending the dedication of the Golden State Mutual Life Insurance Co. murals titled "The Negro in California History," Los Angeles, 1949
AltTitle.other: G.S.M. Murals Conference and Dedication of artwork
Description.note: Group gathered following the unveiling of the two murals titled “The Negro in California History” in the lobby of the Golden State Mutual Life Insurance Company’s new home office building (4261 S. Central Ave.). The murals were painted by artists Hale Woodruff and Charles Alston and installed on the lower walls of the Roman travertine against which the group is standing. Left to right: George Beavers, Jr., chairman of the board, Golden State Mutual; Charlotta Bass, Publisher of the California Eagle, pulled the cord to unveil the Charles Alston Mural; Norman O. Houston, President, Golden State Mutual; Gussie Woods, mother of Hale Woodruff, pulled the cord to unveil the Woodruff mural; and Titus Alexander, member of the California Historical Society who aided in the research upon which the murals are based.
Sub-series: Monuments, Murals, Exhibitions, and Anniversaries of Early Los Angeles, 1949-1981
